section.title: Introduction
section.p: Quantum GIS (QGIS) is designed to be a Geographic Information System (GIS) built for Linux/Unix. QGIS will ultimately offer support for vector, raster, and database formats.

ul.li: Support for spatially enabled PostgreSQL tables using PostGIS
Support for ESRI shapefiles and other vector formats support by the OGR library
Support for raster formats supported by the GDAL library
Change vector symbology (single, graduated, and continuous)

section.title: Getting Started
section.p: This section gives you a quick overview of running QGIS and examining data in a set of shapefiles.

section.title: Installation
section.p: Installation of QGIS is documented in the Installation Guide.

section.title: Starting QGIS
section.p: Assuming the QGIS is installed in the PATH, you can start QGIS by typing: qgis.
When QGIS starts, an empty window is displayed as shown below.
section.note: Your window decorations (title bar, etc.) may appear different depending on your operating system and window manager

section.title: Loading a Shapefile
section.p: To load one or more shapefiles, click on the Add Layer button .
The Select one or more layers to add dialog box will be displayed.
Navigate to the directory where the shapefiles reside. Select one or more files and click ok to load them.
When QGIS loads a layer, it assigns a random color to it as shown below.

section.title: Changing Symbology
section.p: To make the layer more appealing, open the Layer Properties dialog by right-clicking on a layer name in the table of contents (left side of the QGIS window) and selecting Properties.

If you like, change the display name of the layer by editing the Display name field. Click on the Symbology tab and click on the Outline color and Fill color and select a new color from the color chooser. You can also change the line width if desired.
